aaand another line

L.S: Cut the aubergine into 1 cm thick slices and then fry in batches. Set aside once done.
Whilst the aubergines are frying, start on the tomato sauce. Dice the onions and fry. Chop the garlic, dried chillies and peppers and add to the onions.

When the onions are soft, add a dash of red wine to deglaze the pan. Then add the chopped tomatoes, tomato puree. Season with salt and pepper and add some dried herbs such as oregano. Turn down the heat and leave to simmer for as long as possible.

Grate the parmesan then layer the elements in a baking tray, starting with the tomato and finishing with parmesan. There will be enough aubergine for approximately 3 layers in a 30 cm by 20 cm baking tray.

Notes.S: 1kg of aubergines is approximately 4 small or 3 big ones. Can add cheese such as mozzarella and ricotta. If you have left-over slices of fried aubergine, they go surprisingly well in cheese toasties.

L.S: Pre­heat oven to 200°C (180°C fan) mark 6. Mix the oil, gar­lic and spices in a small bowl. Cut the sweet potato and butternut squash into chunks.
Place the onion and squash in a medium roast­ing tin or oven­proof serv­ing dish, add half the spiced oil and toss to coat. Roast for 15min.
Pick the leaves from half the thyme sprigs and stir into re­main­ing spiced oil.
Stir beans, to­ma­toes, bar­be­cue sauce and re­main­ing thyme sprigs into the roast­ing tin/dish with 150ml (5fl oz) wa­ter; sea­son gen­er­ously. Re­turn to the oven for 20min.
Brush mush­rooms all over with the reserved spiced oil, nes­tle into the to­mato/bean mix­ture and cook for 15-20min, un­til ten­der.
Scat­ter over spring onions and serve with yo­gurt (reg­u­lar or dairy-free), if you like.

Notes.S: You can add any veg to this, peppers and aubergines go well and any beans you have will work. I don't usually have it with Yoghurt.

L.S: Bring the Dashi to the boil, turn down, add the seaweed and simmer for 5 mins. Add any extras here that need cooking.
Separately whisk up the miso with a cup of broth until it's as smooth as possible. Stir in the miso mixture and mirin. Ensuring it's fully dissolved, be careful not to boil.
Add the spring onions and any other garnishes to serve.

Notes.S:
Typically I will add some interesting mushrooms, carrots, greens and silken tofu cut up small enough that they will boil quickly in the broth before the miso goes in.

One sachet of powdered dashi (or ~5g) for about 1 litre (4 cups) of water

L.S: Roast the red pepper and red chillies.
Tip all the beans into a large colander and rinse under cold water, using your hands to separate the beans. Drain well and tip the beans into the bowl of a slow cooker on low.

Add the tomatoes, red pepper, onion, garlic, stock powder, cumin, chopped green chillies and chilli powder to the beans and season generously with salt and pepper. Give everything a good stir to combine. Cover and cook for 6 hours, until the mixture is aromatic and the beans are thickly coated in the sauce
Melt chocolate & butter.
Add sugar, then flour, then eggs.
Cook at 180 C for 40mins.

Name.S: Butter bean and butternut squash ragout

L.S: Zest lemons and beat with cream cheese and caster sugar.
Gradually beat in 75ml of lemon juice until thickened.
Fold in creme fraiche.
For the biscuit base, melt butter. Crush the biscuits then mix in with the butter and stir in the sugar.
Put the biscuit base at the bottom of the tin then top with cream mixture. Chill overnight. Top with fruit to serve.
Finely chop the leeks then fry in 1 tbsp olive oil along with a pinch of salt for 15 minutes. Until softened and golden brown.
Put the mushrooms in a food processor and pulse until they're very finely chopped.
Scrape the leeks out of the pan and into a bowl. Heat more oil in the pan and fry the mushrooms for 10 mins over medium heat.
Finely chop the garlic and sage then add to the pan with the miso and mustard and fry for another minute, then leave to cool slightly.

Combine the mushrooms, leeks, finely chopped chestnuts, grated cheese and breadcrumbs in a bowl. Season with pepper and maybe a little salt then work everything together until you have a slightly stodgy mixture.

Unravel the puff pastry on a floured surface, then roll out so one side measures about 40cm. Push the mushroom mixture down the centre of the pastry. Bring the pastry around the mixture and seal the edges with a fork, then cut into 8 pieces. Lay on a lined baking sheet and brush each one with the beaten egg. Bake in the oven for 25-30 mins on 180°C/200°C until deep, golden brown.
Thinly slice leeks and slice the garlic, then cook them in butter until soft.
Tip into a bowl with breadcrumbs, diced blue cheese, chestnut puree, 3 eggs, grated nutmeg, halved chestnuts.
Wilt spinach, leave to cool then squeeze out liquid.
Put the spinach into the bowl, add seasoning then chill for 1 hour.
Roll out the pastry, spoon the filling into the middle then fold the pastry over it.
Glaze with egg,  poke holes then bake for 40 mins at 200 C (fan).
Glaze again and bake for another 10 mins.

Name.S: Chestnut, Spinach & Blue Cheese En Croute

L.S: Cream the butter with sugars, then add vanilla essence.
Beat in the egg.
Sift in flour & salt then fold in.
Add any extras (e.g. chocolate chips or sultanas) around 2-4 oz.
Cook for 180 C for 12-15mins.
Preheat the oven to 160 C. Grease and line 20cm square tin.
Gently heat the butter, sugar and golden syrup until melted.
Stir in the oats.
Bake for 25 mins.
Cool for 10 mins before cutting into squares. Remove from the tin when cool.
Preheat oven to 180C.
Heat chocolate, milk & 3oz sugar until melted.
Beat butter and sugar until pale & creamy. Beat in eggs, vanilla essence and chocolate milk gradually.
Sift flour, cocoa & bicarbonate of soda.
Bake for 30-35 mins.

Notes.S: A good icing to go with. Beat 4oz butter and 7oz icing sugar together. Mix in 4oz chocolate and 1tbsp milk melted together

L.S: Preheat the oven to 180 C.
Finely slice the onion and fry on low heat.
Trim the green beans and chop into 1-inch pieces. Fry with the onion for 5 mins.
Add chopped tomatoes, lentils, 300ml of water, oregano, thyme, salt and pepper.
Simmer for 30 mins.
Make the cheese sauce and soak lasagne sheets in boiling water.
Layer up the lasagne and bake for 30 - 40 mins.

Name.S: Green Bean and Red Lentil Lasagne

L.S: Put the linguine into a pan that is large enough that the linguine can lie flat. Chop the tomatoes in half and add them, along with the lemon zest, oil and some salt. Add 500ml of boiling water and cover with a lid. As soon as the water is boiling, remove the lid and let simmer on high heat for 6 minutes, turning occasionally.

Meanwhile, remove the stalks from the kale. Once the 6 minutes is up, as the kale to the pasta and cook for approximately 2 more minutes (or until the pasta is cooked and most of the water evaporated).
Serve in bowls and top with parmesan

Notes.S: Can replace the kale with spinach

L.S: Bring a saucepan of water to the boil and add the linguine and some salt.
Chop the garlic, dried chillies (adjust the quantity according to the spice and your taste) and parsley stalks. Set the parsley leaves aside for later.
Add a generous amount of olive oil to a separate pan and slowly fry the chopped ingredients.
While that is frying, cut the cherry tomatoes in half and roughly chop the parsley leaves.
Once the pasta is approximately half cooked, add the tomatoes to the garlic and continue to fry.
When the tomatoes are partially cooked, add a large glug of white wine and stir well. Leave for a minute or so before adding the prawns and chopped parsley.

By now, your pasta should be ready. Drain it and add it into the other pan (ensuring the prawns are cooked before you add the pasta). Mix well and serve. There is generally lots of liquid left at the end to mop up with the bread.

Notes.S: It is possible to chop and cook everything while the linguine is cooking but it may be easier to prep everything before. This is a take on Spaghetti alle Vongole but linguine is better and clams are hard to come by.

L.S: Soften finely chopped onions.
Make a paste of the garlic, ginger and chillies. Then add to the onions and cook for < 5 mins.
Add turmeric and garam masala, mix then add the passata and salt.
Blanch the spinach in a couple of centimetres of water.
Puree the spinach then add to the sauce.
Add cream to taste and mix in thumbnail-sized chunks of paneer.
Cook for 5 mins then serve.
Roughly chop the parsley leaves and blend with the garlic, nuts and oil until it has a smooth consistency.
Transfer to a bowl and stir through the parmesan, zest of the lemon and seasoning.

Notes.S: This goes well with gnocchi and green beans. This amount will cover around 500g of gnocchi.

L.S: Mix all ingredients together.
Slice then fry the mushrooms until golden, season then put aside.
Finely dice then fry the onion until soft. Add chopped thyme and garlic and fry for 1 min.
Add the pearl barley, mix then gradually add the stock. Simmer for 25-30 mins until the pearl barley is tender and the stock has all been absorbed.
Stir in the spinach, cheese, mushrooms and seasoning. Let the spinach wilt and then serve.
Mix all the ingredients together. Maybe adjust the quantities so that the dough isn't too sticky.
Knead for 5 mins, until well mixed and not too sticky.
Either use immediately or wait to prove, this will make the taste stronger. If you leave it to prove, press (but don't fold) the air out before using.
Mix together Mirin and soy sauces for the marinade and put in a jar.
Bring a pan of salted water to the boil on high heat then lower to low/ medium heat.
Spoon in the eggs and cook for the desired time (see notes).
After the time is up, spoon the eggs into an ice bath until cool enough to handle.
Peel the eggs and put them in the marinade for 2 -24 hours, the longer the better.

Notes.S:
Can substitute dark soy sauce with an equal amount of regular soy sauce + 1 tbsp brown sugar.
The marinade can be kept in the fridge in an airtight container for up to 3 weeks
Egg cooking times:
5 ½ minutes for set, but soft egg whites and runny egg yolks – these eggs are really delicate.
6 minutes for a set white, but runny egg yolk.
6 ½ minutes for a set white, a jammy/runny egg yolk, and as seen in the pictures in this post.
7 minutes for a set white, and a half set egg yolk.

L.S: Cut up the peppers and fry in the oil until soft, don't brown. Then let cool.
Blitz all ingredients   oil from the pan until smooth.
(Optional) Sprinkle with chives.

Name.S: Roasted Beetroot and Goats Cheese Risotto

L.S: Chop the mango and chillies and squeeze in the lime juice. Season with salt and pepper then pour over the salmon fillets and leave to marinade.
Remove the salmon fillets and fry. Add the mango mixture towards the end and cook until warmed through.

Notes.S: Try with a bit of coriander. Try without marinading the salmon and having the meal cold.

L.S: Heat a large pan over medium heat and add the 4 tbsp olive oil, diced bread and a pinch of salt then cook until toasted on the outside (~10mins).
Add the bread to a large bowl along with the beans, sliced tomatoes, chopped spinach, diced pepper, diced onion and crumbled feta.

Whisk together 1/2 cup olive oil, 3 tbsp red wine vinegar, 2 tbsp chopped basil, 1 minced garlic clove, 1/2 tsp dijon mustard, 1/2 tsp maple syrup (or something similar), 1/2 tsp salt and 1/2 tsp black pepper.
Pour the vinegarette over the salad and mix together.
Preheat the oven to 200°C (180°C fan). Place a large saucepan over a medium heat and add about a tablespoon of olive or rapeseed oil.

Cut Sweet Potato into 1.5cm cubes, skin on. Put them onto a large roasting tray and drizzle over some oil. Sprinkle over 1 teaspoon of cumin seeds, ½ teaspoon of fennel seeds and some salt and pepper. Roast for around 25 minutes until the sweet potato has started to colour around the edges.
Add 2 diced red onions to the large saucepan and fry for 5 minutes then add 4 chopped garlic cloves, 3 tablespoons of chopped ginger and 2 chopped green chillis. Fry for 10 minutes or so.

Bash 2 teaspoons each of cumin and coriander seeds in a pestle and mortar then add to the saucepan along with 1½ teaspoons of turmeric and 1 teaspoon of cinnamon. Fry for a minute, stirring well to make sure that the spices don’t burn.

Add 400g red lentils, 400ml coconut milk and 1 litre of vegetable stock to the saucepan and stir well. Once the dhal starts to bubble, turn the heat down and simmer for around 25 minutes or until the lentils have softened. Add a little water from a boiled kettle if the consistency of the dhal gets too thick.

Add 250g fresh spinach, a large handful of chopped coriander (reserving a few leaves to garnish at the end) and the juice from 2 lemons. Taste the dhal and adjust the seasoning if needed then remove the saucepan from the heat. Pour the dhal into bowls and top with the roasted sweet potato cubes and remaining coriander leaves.
Mix all of the ingredients except for the salmon and sesame seeds.
Pour the sauce over the salmon and leave to marinate. This step can be skipped to speed up prep time.
Heat a frying pan, add the salmon and pour the sauce in.
The sauce will reduce and thicken as the salmon is cooking. Continuously spoon the sauce onto the salmon to leave it with a glaze.
Add the sesame seeds to serve.

Notes.S: Measurements are estimates and will be updated after testing.,
